Clinical triad of Coma, dehydration and audotie breathing in not known diabetic child should raise the possibilty of DKA.
Correction of shock, acidosis & dehydration by IV fluid is the most urgent line of therapy in DKA.
Which of the following is true about DKA?
options: May be 1st manifestation in 20% of diabetes

questions.stem: Diabetes mellitus presents by all of the following except:
options: DKA represents the initial presentation in 10-20% of cases.

questions.stem: All of the following are acute complications of TYPE I Diabetes mellitus except:
All of the following statements about DKA management are true except:
options: Initial plasma potassium may be low or high
The use of bicarbonate for correction of acidosis in DKA is not recommended early
Insulin therapy started after 1h from fluid therapy
0.9 % saline is used in hyperosmolar cases

questions.stem: Which of the following is an acute complication for type 1 DM in children?
Insulin deficiency is associated with:
All of the following investigations for congenital hypothyroidism are true except:
options: Thyroid scanning is essential for diagnosis of the cause.

questions.stem: Congenital Hypothyroidism associated with all of the following except?
All of the following are true about the management of DKA EXCEPT:
options: IV fluid Correction must be gradual as rapid rehydration lead to cerebral edema.
When blood glucose has fallen to≤ 300 mg/dl add glucose to the IV fluids to avoid hypoglycemia.
If the patient shows mild dehydration, you start the deficit + maintenance therapy without bolus fluids.
Insulin therapy starts with resuscitation fluid therapy.
Diabetic ketoacidosis represents the initial presentation of DM in 10-20 % of cases.

questions.stem: Which statement isn`t true regarding Potassium therapy during of management of DKA?
options: Initial plasma potassium level may be low or high.
Potassium therapy start after the IV fluid resuscitation
Potassium therapy start after the patient passes urine provided K is not elevated.
Plasma potassium level will rise following treatment with insulin.
Potassium is added 30-40 mEq/L after the first hour of IV fluid therapy.

questions.stem: A one year old child presented with the history of short stature, tiredness and constipation. Examination revealed a palpable goiter, Serum T4 was decreased and TSH levels were increased. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
Iodine deficiency can cause:
In type 1 diabetes, the pancreas can’t make insulin because:
options: The child is overweight or obese
The body’s immune system has attacked the pancreas
The patient eats more simple carbs than the body can handle

questions.stem: children with type 1 diabetes need to:
options: Take insulin in shots or with a pump

questions.stem: What is the first step in the management of diabetic ketoacidosis?
options: To initiate insulin and fluids simultaneously

questions.stem: Down Syndrome, also known as trisomy 21, is the most common cause of mental retardation and is considered a:
What is the number of chromosomes in nondisjunction cases of Down syndrome?
The LEAST likely clinical situation for suspecting chromosomal abnormalities is:
Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by all of the following except:
options: It affects individuals in every generation.
Phenotypically normal parents do not transmit the disease to the child.
It affects males more commonly than females.

questions.stem: Autosomal recessive disorders are characterized by all of the following except:
options: Chance of disease transmission is increased by positive consanguinity
Recurrence risk with each pregnancy of 50%

questions.stem: The following are found in a newborn term infant with Down syndrome EXCEPT:
Which of the following is correct about Down syndrome?
options: Late maternal age is commonly seen in the translocation type.
Delayed milestones are seen in only 25% of cases.

questions.stem: Turner syndrome is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:
Genetic counseling is indicated in which of the following conditions?
A ring chromosome is a special type of chromosomal:
The recurrence risk of multifactorial inheritance is typically:
The following clinical situations suggest a genetic disorder EXCEPT:
Which of the following is true about Down syndrome?
options: About 1% are due to a translocation phenomenon.
Incidence increases with increased paternal age.
Some degree of mental retardation is always found.

questions.stem: A disease passed on only through the mother and affecting both sons and daughters is most likely:
All of the following are possible complications in Down syndrome EXCEPT:
options: Hearing problems due to secretory otitis media

questions.stem: Prader-Willi syndrome was diagnosed in a toddler with early feeding difficulties who gained a lot of weight in the second year of life. This genetic disorder is:
options: Due to gene deletion on chromosome 15.
A gene defect inherited from the father.

questions.stem: Y-linked inheritance includes:
Which of the following is the most common presentation in Klinefelter’s syndrome?
A 10-year-old male presented with mental retardation, a long face, large everted ears, a prominent mandible, and a PCR detected CGG repeat of more than 250. The most likely diagnosis is:
Fragile X syndrome is a common cause of inherited intellectual disability in males. The mode of inheritance is:

Which of the following has a numerical autosomal inheritance pattern?
Niemann–Pick disease is:
The gene involved in Fragile X syndrome is:
What is the type of inheritance in tuberous sclerosis?
Which of the following exhibits autosomal dominant inheritance?
Neurofibromatosis I is:
The most common malignancy seen in a child with Down’s syndrome is:
Which is the characteristic feature of Tay-Sachs disease and other metabolic diseases affecting neurons?
options: A cherry-red spot in the macula
Onion peel appearance in the neurons
The waxy white appearance of the fundus

questions.stem: Angelman syndrome is due to:
What is the type of inheritance in MELAS?
Paternal chromosome 15 deletion is seen in:

Coarctation of the aorta is common in which syndrome?

A newborn infant has dysmorphic features. The pregnancy was complicated by breech presentation, decreased fetal movements, and polyhydramnios. The child demonstrates hypotonia, a flat face, flattened occiput, epicanthal folds, and abdominal distention. The most likely cause of this child's dysmorphology is:
questions.explanation: The clinical picture described, including a flat face, flattened occiput, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, and abdominal distention, are classic characteristic features of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). While other syndromes might present with some of these signs, this specific combination is most indicative of Down syndrome.

questions.stem: A couple comes to you following the diagnosis of trisomy 21 in their 18-week fetus. They ask what medical problems may be anticipated for a child who has Down syndrome. Of the following, the medical problem that is encountered most frequently in infants who have trisomy 21 is:
questions.explanation: Down syndrome is characterized by several clinical features and associated anomalies. Among the neurological features, generalized hypotonia in the first two years of life is a key characteristic. While cardiac defects are common, affecting about 40% of cases, and duodenal atresia is also an associated anomaly, generalized hypotonia is a constant and prominent feature.

questions.stem: A small for gestational age newborn is delivered at term following an uneventful pregnancy to a gravida 3, para 2, 34-year-old woman by normal spontaneous vaginal delivery. On physical examination, the newborn is noted to have a small chin, a clenched fist and hypotonia. Which of the following, the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical features of Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) include low birth weight, microcephaly with a prominent occiput, small ears, and overlapping fingers (clenched fist). The presentation of a small-for-gestational-age infant with a small chin, a clenched fist, and hypotonia is most consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.stem: During health supervision visit for a 5-year-old boy with hemophilia A, her mother reports that she herself is currently 16 weeks pregnant. She expresses concern about this pregnancy because her brother and two of her maternal uncles died from complications of hemophilia A. She was told at the time of her most recent ultrasonography that she is carrying a male fetus. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case?
questions.explanation: Hemophilia A is listed as an example of an X-linked recessive disorder. The pattern of inheritance described—where the disease affects males (the son, brother, and maternal uncles of the pregnant woman) and is passed through the maternal line—is characteristic of an X-linked recessive condition.

questions.stem: The parents of a child who is suffering from a metabolic disease characterized by an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern ask for your advice they intend to have a second baby. What is the risk of having affected child?
questions.explanation: In autosomal recessive inheritance, both parents must be heterozygous carriers (phenotypically normal) for the abnormal gene to pass the disease to their child. In this scenario, since they have already had an affected child (who must be homozygous), both parents are confirmed carriers. The recurrence risk with each subsequent pregnancy for two heterozygous parents is 25% for an affected child, 50% for a carrier child, and 25% for a phenotypically and genotypically normal child.

questions.stem: A mentally retarded 15-yr-old boy is found to have macroorchidism and large. prominent ears. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of Fragile X syndrome in males is characterized by mental retardation, macro-orchidism (after puberty), large ears, and a long face with a prominent mandible. This combination of features strongly points to Fragile X syndrome.

questions.stem: The mother of 1 year old boy complains that her child still can't sit unsupported. On examination the child has dysmorphic features and a transverse palmar crease. Local examination of the heart reveals a murmur over the left parasternal area. One of the complications of this condition is:
questions.explanation: The description of the child not being able to sit unsupported at 1 year of age, along with dysmorphic features and a transverse palmar crease, points to Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). The textbook states that one of the complications of Down syndrome is a higher incidence of hypothyroidism.

questions.stem: A 7 month male boy presented with acute onset of pallor & jaundice. Hb=3 gm/dl & reticulocytes =10%, the baby was completely healthy till he shared food with his family yesterday. What do you want to ask about?
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation of acute pallor and jaundice with severe anemia (Hb=3 gm/dl) and high reticulocytes suggests acute hemolysis. The history of eating family food yesterday suggests a potential dietary trigger for a condition like G6PD deficiency. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder, which means family history, particularly in males (like a brother) and maternal lineage, is highly relevant. Given that it's a genetic disorder, parental consanguinity increases the risk of autosomal recessive conditions, and while G6PD is X-linked, a comprehensive genetic history is always prudent in these situations. Therefore, all these questions are relevant to reaching a diagnosis.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old child has growth retardation and dysmorphic features had a history of surgically repaired endocardial cushion defect. This case might be:
questions.explanation: Endocardial cushion defect is a type of cardiac anomaly that is commonly associated with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), affecting about 40% of cases. The presence of growth retardation and dysmorphic features in a child with this specific cardiac history makes Down syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

questions.stem: The mother of a 4 months old boy complains that her child still can't support his head. On examination the child has a flat occiput, and a transverse palmar crease. Local examination of the heart shows a hollow systolic murmur over the left parasternal area. One of the complications of this condition is:
questions.explanation: The combination of a 4-month-old boy with delayed head support, flat occiput, and a transverse palmar crease points to Down syndrome. The textbook explicitly lists a higher incidence of leukemia as a complication of Down syndrome.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old child has brachiocephaly, intellectual delay had a history of surgically repaired duodenal atresia at birth. This case might be:
questions.explanation: Brachycephaly (flat occiput) and intellectual delay are features of Down syndrome. Duodenal atresia is a well-known associated gastrointestinal anomaly found in infants with Down syndrome and is often surgically repaired at birth. This constellation of findings strongly suggests Down syndrome as the diagnosis.

questions.stem: An infant with severe vomiting since birth. Abdominal X-ray shows double-bubble sign. Pan-systolic murmur is present over the pericardium. What is most helpful in his examination?
questions.explanation: The double-bubble sign on an abdominal X-ray indicates duodenal atresia, a gastrointestinal anomaly associated with Down syndrome. The presence of a pan-systolic murmur suggests a cardiac defect, also common in Down syndrome. A critical feature of Down syndrome is generalized hypotonia, which would be an important part of the physical examination to support the suspected diagnosis.

questions.stem: A 6 years old male infant with Down syndrome is brought by his mother because of prolonged fever. On examination he is found to have an enlarged spleen 5 cm below left costal margin. What is the most appropriate investigation to be ordered?
questions.explanation: Prolonged fever and hepatosplenomegaly in a child with Down syndrome, who has a higher incidence of leukemia, is a red flag for a possible hematological malignancy. A complete blood picture (CBC) is the initial and most appropriate investigation to screen for leukemia.

questions.stem: An infant 2 days old presenting with persistent vomiting. He has dysmorphic features and severe hypotonia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Down syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by dysmorphic features and severe hypotonia. Persistent vomiting in an infant with Down syndrome can be caused by associated anomalies such as duodenal atresia. The combination of dysmorphic features, hypotonia, and early vomiting is highly suggestive of Down syndrome.

questions.stem: A four month old female infant is brought for follow up. On examination she is found to have a systolic murmur on the left side of the chest. The skin on both sides of the neck was unusually redundant. What would you expect to find in the rest of the examination?
questions.explanation: The presence of a systolic murmur and redundant skin of the neck (webbing of the neck) in a female infant is highly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45 XO). A common cardiac anomaly associated with this syndrome is coarctation of the aorta, which would manifest as a weak or absent femoral pulse.

questions.stem: A routine prenatal ultrasound reveals a male fetus with meningomyelocele. You counsel her about the etiology of this defect and the risk of recurrence. The correct statement is
options: Diagnosis can be made by detection of very low levels of alpha fetoprotein in the amniotic fluid
Environmental factors will not affect the incidence of the disease.
Supplementation of maternal diet with folate decreases the incidence of this condition
This condition is transmitted as autosomal recessive
questions.explanation: Meningomyelocele is an example of a neural tube defect, which falls under multifactorial inheritance. This means its development is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. Maternal supplementation with folate is known to significantly decrease the incidence of neural tube defects.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old girl had surgery for aortic lesion. She is always short for her age.. This case might be
questions.explanation: Turner syndrome (45,XO) is a sex chromosomal abnormality that affects females. A key feature is short stature, and a common associated cardiac anomaly is coarctation of the aorta, a type of aortic lesion. The patient's presentation of short stature and a history of surgery for an aortic lesion is classic for Turner syndrome.

questions.stem: The mother of a boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy tells you that her brother was similarly affected and died in his teenage years. What is the pattern of inheritance in this case
questions.explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a classic example of an X-linked recessive disorder. This is supported by the fact that the disease affects a male child and his maternal uncle (the mother's brother), following the characteristic pattern of X-linked recessive inheritance.

questions.stem: A 14-year-old boy was referred because of tall stature. His height was more than the 95th percentile. He had bilateral small testes, no pubic or axillary hair. The cause of such condition is
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of a male with disproportionate tall stature, small testes, and absence of secondary sexual characteristics is characteristic of Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY). This condition is a result of an extra X chromosome and is a form of hypogonadism.

questions.stem: A female infant born to a 24-year-old woman has been diagnosed clinically as having Down syndrome. The mother is concerned about her risk of having another baby with Down syndrome. The most appropriate investigation to determine the risk of recurrence is
options: Determination of serum alpha-fetoprotein in the infant
Determination of serum alpha-fetoprotein in the mother
Karyotyping for the infant and mother
questions.explanation: While the risk of Down syndrome is dependent on maternal age, in younger mothers, a translocation form of Trisomy 21 is more likely. This translocation can be inherited from a parent who is a balanced translocation carrier. Therefore, karyotyping is needed for both the infant to confirm the type of trisomy and for the mother to rule out if she is a carrier of a balanced translocation, which would significantly affect the recurrence risk for future pregnancies.

questions.stem: A two-day- old male infant is referred to the hospital for bilious vomiting and a heart murmur. The baby was born at 37 weeks gestation to a 39 year old woman who had no prenatal care. X ray chest and abdomen were done. Which of the following is the most likely to be in the x ray?
questions.explanation: The patient's age (2 days), maternal age (39 years), and symptoms (bilious vomiting, heart murmur) point to a diagnosis of Down syndrome with duodenal atresia. Duodenal atresia is characterized on an abdominal X-ray by the 'double bubble sign,' which represents air trapped in the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

questions.stem: A 17-year-old girl is 138cm tall. Her father is 175cm tall and her mother is 164cm tall. She has always been short and she had cardiac surgery at the age of 1 year. Her pubertal breast stage is Tanner B1. Which of the following is most likely to diagnose the cause of all her medical problems?
questions.explanation: The patient's short stature (138 cm at age 17), history of cardiac surgery at 1 year old, and lack of pubertal development (Tanner B1) are all classic features of Turner syndrome (45, XO). Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder, and a chromosomal analysis (karyotyping) is the definitive diagnostic tool.

questions.stem: A disease affecting all of the daughters but none of the sons of an affected father, and 50% of the sons or daughters of an affected mother, is most likely:
questions.explanation: This pattern of inheritance is characteristic of X-linked dominant disorders. An affected father will pass his single X chromosome to all of his daughters, making all of them affected. He cannot pass the trait to his sons, as they inherit his Y chromosome. An affected mother (who is heterozygous) has a 50% chance of passing the dominant X chromosome to either her sons or daughters.

questions.stem: A disease passed only through the mother and affecting both sons and daughters, with variable manifestations in the affected siblings, is most likely:
questions.explanation: Mitochondrial inheritance is exclusively transmitted by the mother, as the sperm does not contribute mitochondria to the zygote. The disease can affect both sons and daughters, and variable manifestations can occur due to heteroplasmy, which is the presence of a mix of normal and mutated mitochondrial DNA within a single cell.

questions.stem: Genetic diseases of numerical chromosomal abnormalities include:
questions.explanation: The textbook classifies genetic disorders into chromosomal abnormalities, single-gene disorders, and multifactorial inheritance. Down syndrome is explicitly listed as a numerical autosomal abnormality, specifically Trisomy 21. Gaucher disease, hemophilia, and thalassemia major are single-gene disorders.

questions.stem: One of the following anomalies is not associated with Down syndrome:
questions.explanation: The clinical features associated with Down syndrome include congenital heart disease (40% of cases), mental retardation, and a simian crease (50% of cases). Macroorchidism (abnormally large testes) is a feature of Fragile X syndrome, not Down syndrome.

questions.stem: A patient with 45 XO karyotype and short stature is likely to have:
questions.explanation: Turner syndrome is a sex chromosomal abnormality with a karyotype of 45, XO. A characteristic feature of this syndrome is short stature.

questions.stem: Autosomal recessive disorders are characterized by:
questions.explanation: Autosomal recessive disorders are characterized by a greater incidence of parental consanguinity because the chance of both parents carrying the same recessive gene increases within families. These disorders affect males and females equally, have phenotypically normal carriers, and often show 'skipping' of generations in a family pedigree.

questions.stem: Characteristic feature of autosomal recessive inheritance is:
questions.explanation: A characteristic feature of autosomal recessive inheritance is that affected individuals must inherit the gene from both parents, but the parents themselves can be phenotypically normal carriers. The risk of recurrence for each child of two carrier parents is 25%, and the disorder affects males and females equally.

questions.stem: X-linked recessive inheritance is characterized by:
options: All daughters of a carrier mother will be carriers
The affected father never transmits the disease to his sons
questions.explanation: In X-linked inheritance, a son inherits his X chromosome from his mother and his Y chromosome from his father. Therefore, an affected father cannot transmit the disease to his sons. The disease shows a male preference, and a carrier mother has a 50% chance of having an affected son and a 50% chance of having a carrier daughter.

questions.stem: Ring chromosome is a special type of chromosomal
questions.explanation: The textbook defines a ring chromosome as a specific type of deletion where both ends of the chromosome are lost and the two broken ends rejoin to form a ring.

questions.stem: Chromosomal structural abnormalities include:
questions.explanation: The textbook classifies chromosomal abnormalities into numerical and structural types. Monosomy, Trisomy, and non-disjunction are all examples of numerical abnormalities. Translocation is a type of structural abnormality.

questions.stem: Chromosomal numerical abnormalities include:
questions.explanation: The textbook explicitly lists Trisomy as a numerical abnormality, defined as one extra chromosome. Duplication and translocation are structural abnormalities.

questions.stem: Sex linked disorders do not include
questions.explanation: G-6-PD deficiency and hemophilia are both examples of X-linked recessive disorders. Hairy pinna is an example of a Y-linked disorder (holanderic inheritance). Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that is not a sex-linked genetic condition.

questions.stem: The following is not a feature in newborn term infant with Down syndrome:
questions.explanation: Down syndrome features include brachydactyly (short and broad hands), clinodactyly (incurving of the 5th finger), and generalized hypotonia. Webbing of the neck is a characteristic feature of Turner syndrome (45, XO), not Down syndrome.

questions.stem: If a parent had hereditary spherocytosis, the chance to have an affected baby is:
questions.explanation: The textbook lists hereditary spherocytosis as an autosomal dominant disorder. In an autosomal dominant condition, a single copy of the abnormal gene is enough to cause the disease. An affected parent who is heterozygous has a 50% chance of passing the gene to each child.

questions.stem: X-linked recessive disorders include:
questions.explanation: The textbook explicitly lists Duchenne muscular dystrophy as an X-linked recessive disorder. Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder, sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder, and Vitamin-D resistant rickets is an X-linked dominant disorder.

questions.stem: Autosomal recessive inheritance is found in:
questions.explanation: Galactosemia is listed as a metabolic disease with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. G-6-PD deficiency and Hemophilia-B are X-linked recessive disorders, while Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal dominant disorder.

questions.stem: A series of three nucleotides on a gene that encodes an amino acid is called:
A ring chromosome is a special type of chromosomal:
This assessment finding would enable a nurse to suspect the presence of Down syndrome in a newborn:
options: Short palpebral tissues and flat maxillary area
Prominent scalp veins and a high-pitched cry
Persistent postnatal growth lag and Microcephaly
Microcephaly, scalp defects and cleft lip

questions.stem: On which of the following are chromosomal disorders based?
options: Mutant allele and their defective products
Imbalance in chromosome number and chromosome arrangement
Mutant allele and imbalance in chromosome number

questions.stem: What will be the condition of the progeny if the father is normal, while the mother has one gene for hemophilia and one gene for color blindness on one of the X chromosomes?
options: Only daughters are hemophilic and color blind
Both sons and daughters will be hemophilic and color blind
50% hemophilic and color blind sons and 50% normal sons
50% hemophilic color blind daughters and 50% color blind daughters

questions.stem: All the following are features of mitochondrial inheritance except:
The following are found in a newborn term infant with Down syndrome EXCEPT:
Prader-Willi syndrome was diagnosed in a toddler with early feeding difficulties who gained a lot of weight in the second year of life. This genetic disorder is:
options: Due to gene deletion on chromosome 15
A gene defect inherited from the father

questions.stem: Down syndrome is characterized by all the following except:
The following are characteristic features of autosomal dominant inheritance EXCEPT:
options: Males and females are equally affected
Both parents carried the affected gene

questions.stem: All the following are characteristic features of autosomal recessive inheritance EXCEPT:
options: No affected family members in other generations
Males and females are equally affected

questions.stem: The recurrence risk of multifactorial inheritance is characterized by all the following EXCEPT:
options: It is related to the incidence of the disease in the community.
It is similar among all 1st-degree relatives.
It increases when multiple family members are affected.
It is greater when the disorder is more severe.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old child presents with severe episodes of intermittent colicky abdominal pain, vomiting and bleeding per rectum. There was a recent history of an attack of diarrhea. A tubular mass is palpated in the right lower quadrant. To reach the diagnosis you should request:
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation of a 2-year-old with severe, colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and bleeding per rectum, particularly after a history of diarrhea, along with a palpable tubular mass, is highly suggestive of intussusception. An abdominal ultrasound (US) is the diagnostic investigation of choice for this condition.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old child presents with gastroenteritis and moderate dehydration. Serum sodium is 165 mEq/L. In this type of dehydration, which of the following is an expected finding?
questions.explanation: A serum sodium level of 165 mEq/L indicates hypernatremic (hypertonic) dehydration. This type of dehydration is characterized by water loss in excess of electrolyte loss, leading to a hypertonic extracellular fluid (ECF). This causes water to shift out of the cells, leading to cellular dehydration. The clinical signs of cellular dehydration include a very dry tongue and oral mucous membranes.

questions.stem: An 18 month old male is brought to the emergency department with a chief complaint of diarrhea and vomiting for 2 days. His mother describes stools as liquid and foul smelling. He has about 6 episodes of diarrhea and 8 episodes of vomiting per day. His mother reports that he is not feeding well and his activity level is decreased. He seems weak, tired and sleepy. He has a decreased number of wet diapers. On examination, he has severe dehydration. The most important initial management steps:
options: Insert IV line and correct dehydration
Send home advising the mother for giving ORS and excess fluids
questions.explanation: The patient presents with signs of severe dehydration, including lethargy and decreased activity, a decreased number of wet diapers, and a history of vomiting and diarrhea. Severe dehydration is an indication for hospital management with intravenous (IV) fluid therapy. Starting an IV line to correct dehydration is the most important initial step. Antidiarrheal drugs are contraindicated, and oral rehydration solution (ORS) is for mild-to-moderate cases.

questions.stem: A 6-month-old infant has crying spells followed by passage of bloody stools. On examination of abdomen a sausage shaped mass is palpable around the umbilicus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The classic triad of intussusception is sudden, severe, paroxysmal abdominal pain (manifesting as crying spells), a palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools (bloody stools with mucus). The age of onset, clinical picture, and physical exam findings are all highly characteristic of acute intussusception.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old presents with abdominal pain. The pain is described as periumbilical and dull and has occurred almost daily for the past 3 months. The pain does not seem to be related to food intake. His growth and development have been normal, he is not vomiting, and bowel movements are normal. Physical examination is remarkable. Stool and urine analysis are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?
questions.explanation: The patient's pain is described as periumbilical, dull in nature, not severe, and a long duration without interference with daily activities, vomiting, weight loss, or other signs of organic disease. The physical examination and basic lab work (stool and urine analysis) are normal. These features are characteristic of dysfunctional recurrent abdominal pain (also known as psychogenic or nonspecific abdominal pain), which constitutes more than 90% of cases of chronic abdominal pain in children. The appropriate management is reassurance.

questions.stem: A 5-month-old female infant is brought to her physician with a 1-day history of diarrhea. The diarrhea has become more watery since it began. The patient vomited once yesterday but has fed fairly well since that time. On examination, the patient is alert and active. Physical examination is remarkable for dry lips and sticky mucus membranes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?
options: Restrict diet to clear liquids only
questions.explanation: The patient has a history of watery diarrhea and dry mucous membranes, but is still alert and active, indicating she is likely in a state of mild-to-moderate dehydration. The most important line of treatment and the first step in managing a child with mild-to-moderate dehydration is oral rehydration therapy (ORS). IV fluids are for severe dehydration or shock, while antidiarrheal drugs are contraindicated. Diet should not be restricted to clear liquids only; feeding should be resumed shortly after starting rehydration.

questions.stem: A one year old boy presented to the emergency room with severe colicky abdominal pain associated with vomiting and bleeding per rectum. Abdominal examination revealed abdominal mass felt in the right upper quadrant. Rectal examination revealed blood on the finger on withdrawal. The most appropriate line of treatment is:
options: Withdrawal of cow's milk from feeds
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, bleeding per rectum, a palpable abdominal mass, and blood on rectal examination is the classic presentation of intussusception. This condition is a surgical emergency that requires immediate surgical consultation.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old child presents with abdominal pain. The pain is described as dull and not interfering with the child activity. Which of the following manifestations is consistent with organic cause?
questions.explanation: Dysfunctional abdominal pain is typically vague, dull aching in nature, periumbilical in location, and subsides in less than 20 minutes. Organic abdominal pain is often away from the umbilicus, and flank pain is a characteristic symptom of pyelonephritis, a potential organic cause of abdominal pain.

questions.stem: A 5 week old male presented with projectile vomiting after feeding and poor weight gain. On examination, visible peristalsis is seen as a wave moving from left to right across the abdomen. The most appropriate treatment of this condition is:
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation of a 5-week-old infant with projectile, non-bilious vomiting, poor weight gain, and visible gastric peristalsis is classic for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The definitive treatment for this condition is a surgical pyloromyotomy.

questions.stem: A 3 year old boy presents to the ER with history of severe persistent vomiting and diarrhea over the last 36 hours. On examination the child was severely dehydrated, with cold extremities. The skin was mottled, heart rate 160/min and blood pressure 60/30. The expected acid-base disturbance is:
questions.explanation: The patient is in hypovolemic shock due to severe vomiting and diarrhea, as evidenced by severe dehydration, cold mottled skin, tachycardia, and hypotension. Shock leads to tissue hypoperfusion and lactic acid accumulation, which causes metabolic acidosis.

questions.stem: A newborn noticed to have chocking attacks immediately on starting bottle feeding associated with cyanosis. On examination his heart was normal, but his lungs show bilateral crepitations. After two days he was worse and hospitalized. CXR revealed aspiration pneumonia, and he was put on the ventilator. The next step to reach a diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Choking and cyanosis with feeding, along with bilateral lung crepitations and aspiration pneumonia, are classic signs of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) or esophageal atresia. The most common type is esophageal atresia with a tracheo-esophageal fistula. The key diagnostic step is to attempt to pass a nasogastric tube, which will be unable to pass to the stomach and will be seen coiled in the esophageal pouch on an X-ray.

questions.stem: A 5 months old infant presenting to the ER with moderate dehydration. The patient is not shocked. If IV fluid therapy is indicated, what is the most appropriate solution to correct dehydration?
options: Glucose 5%: Saline at a ratio of 1:1 over 8 hours
Glucose 5%: Saline at a ratio of 4:1 over 24 hours
Ringer lactate solution 20 ml/Kg over 1 hour
Ringer lactate solution 20 ml/Kg over 16 hours
questions.explanation: For moderate dehydration without shock, the first step is to correct the fluid deficit. The recommended fluid solution is glucose 5% and saline in a 1:1 ratio, and the deficit should be given over 6-8 hours. The dosage for shock therapy is a bolus of 10-20 ml/kg over 20-30 minutes, not 1 hour or 16 hours.

questions.stem: A 5 months old infant presenting to the ER with mild dehydration. He is fully conscious, not shocked and his weight is 7 Kg. What is the most correct statement about management of dehydration?
options: Ringer lactate solution 20 ml/Kg over 1 hour
ORS followed by maintenance intravenous fluids
questions.explanation: For mild dehydration, the management is oral rehydration therapy (ORS). The volume of ORS for mild dehydration is 50 ml/kg over 4-6 hours. For a 7 kg infant, the required amount is 50x7=350 ml over 4-6 hours.

questions.stem: A one Month old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother, who states that he has projectile vomiting for the past several days. She states that he vomits every time she feeds him and the vomitus is non-bilious. Blood gases revealed hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Expected findings do not include:
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of projectile, non-bilious vomiting in a one-month-old with hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis is classic for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. A 'double bubble sign' on an abdominal X-ray is characteristic of duodenal atresia, an intestinal obstruction that presents at birth with bilious vomiting.

questions.stem: A 4 years old boy presenting to the ER with drooling, vomiting, dysphagia following ingestion of a cleaning agent of unknown nature. The correct management of this case should include:
questions.explanation: The patient has ingested a corrosive agent. In cases of corrosive ingestion, it is contraindicated to induce emesis, perform a stomach wash, or use activated charcoal. The appropriate management includes hospital admission, starting IV fluids, and performing an endoscopy to assess the extent of the injury.

questions.stem: A 4 years old boy presenting to the ER with recent history of ingestion of a disc battery. X-ray showed that the battery is present in the esophagus. There is no vomiting, dysphagia nor abdominal pain. The correct management of this case should include:
questions.explanation: Disc batteries lodged in the esophagus are considered corrosive and can cause significant local tissue injury and perforation. Therefore, even if the patient is asymptomatic, an emergency endoscopic removal is necessary.

questions.stem: Eight months old infant has a 2 day history of diarrhea and poor fluid intake. You diagnose 10 to 15% dehydration. Serum Na is 140 mEq/L. Which of the following fluid is appropriate to begin immediate rehydration?
questions.explanation: The patient has severe dehydration (10-15%) with shock, as indicated by a dehydration level this high. Shock therapy requires immediate administration of intravenous fluid, typically Ringer's lactate or normal saline, at a dose of 10-20 ml/kg over 20-30 minutes.

questions.stem: A 6-month-old baby is admitted with complaint of vomiting and abdominal distention of 36 hours duration. On examination, the baby is dehydrated and the abdomen is distended, there is visible intestinal peristalsis and a mass is palpable in the right hypochondrium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The age of the patient (6 months), the presence of vomiting, abdominal distention, and a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium strongly suggest intussusception. While pyloric stenosis typically presents earlier with non-bilious vomiting and a different mass location, and meconium ileus is a neonatal presentation, intussusception is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in infancy and fits this clinical picture.

questions.stem: A 2-day-old female presents with abdominal distension and vomiting. She has not yet passed a meconium stool. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient is a newborn with abdominal distention, vomiting, and a history of delayed passage of meconium. This is the classic presentation of Hirschsprung disease.

questions.stem: An 8-month-old infant is admitted with history of excessive crying with pain in the abdomen. Child is pale and pain is recurrent. An hour before hospitalization the child was passing blood and mucus per rectum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient's age (8 months), presentation with excessive crying (paroxysmal pain), pallor, and the passage of blood and mucus (red currant jelly stools) are classic signs of intussusception.

questions.stem: A 12-month-old girl has been spitting up her meals since 1-month of age. Her growth is at the ninety-fifth percentile, and she is otherwise asymptomatic and without findings on physical examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The child presents with regurgitation (spitting up), but her growth is excellent, and she has no other symptoms or signs of a serious underlying condition. This is a common presentation of gastroesophageal reflux (GER) in an otherwise healthy infant. The condition is typically benign and self-limiting.

questions.stem: A 10-month-old boy has a 5 hours history of crying with intermittent drawing up his knees to his chest, on the way to the emergency room he passes a loose, bloody stool. Physical examination reveals sausage shaped mass in the right upper quadrant. Plain X ray of the abdomen might show
questions.explanation: The patient's clinical signs (paroxysmal crying, bloody stool, sausage-shaped mass) are classic for intussusception, a type of intestinal obstruction. Intestinal obstruction is characterized on plain abdominal X-ray by the presence of multiple air-fluid levels.

questions.stem: A 13-year old boy presents with a 6-month- history of recurrent abdominal pain and constipation. The pain occurs mostly in the evenings, just before he goes to sleep, Abdominal examination revealed a mass felt in the left lower quadrant. All labs are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: The patient has a history of long-standing constipation and recurrent abdominal pain, with a palpable mass in the left lower quadrant, which is the typical location for an impacted fecal mass. The labs are normal, ruling out other organic causes. This clinical picture is most consistent with functional constipation leading to fecal impaction.

questions.stem: An 18-month-old child presents to the emergency center having had a brief generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He is now postictal and has a temperature of 40°C. During examination he has a large watery stool that has both blood and mucus in it. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: The patient has a high fever, convulsions, and bloody diarrhea. The combination of high fever, bloody diarrhea (enterocolitis), and neurological symptoms (convulsions) in a young child is a known complication of Shigella infection.

questions.stem: A 5 week old boy presents to clinic with vomiting for the last 2 weeks. He is not gaining weight properly. The mother states the vomiting is projectile, non-bilious but she feels that he has a good suck and swallow. Examination revealed an olive like mass felt to the right of umbilicus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient's age (5 weeks), the history of projectile, non-bilious vomiting that started in the last two weeks, poor weight gain, and the pathognomonic finding of an olive-like mass in the abdomen are all classic signs of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

questions.stem: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother. She has had ten watery stools and five vomits in the previous 12 hours. She is eating poorly but drinks eagerly, has no fever and is bright and alert. Her eyes look sunken, but anterior fontanel and capillary refill are normal. There is no blood in the stool and the vomitus is clear yellow in color. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.explanation: According to the dehydration grading table, a child with sunken eyes, normal capillary refill, and a normal fontanel falls into the category of moderate dehydration. The absence of hypotension and tachycardia indicates that the child is not yet in shock.

questions.stem: Proper management of case 26 includes:
questions.explanation: The patient in the previous question has moderate dehydration without shock. The most appropriate management is to administer an oral rehydration solution. Giving antidiarrheal drugs is contraindicated, and feeding should be continued.

questions.stem: A 6 month old breast fed infant has been getting suppositories and enemas every 3-4 days because she does not otherwise defecate. She had neonatal history of delayed passage of meconium. Rectal examination finds an empty rectum. This infant most probably has:
questions.explanation: The classic triad of Hirschsprung disease includes a history of delayed passage of meconium, chronic constipation requiring intervention (suppositories, enemas), and an empty rectum on digital examination.

questions.stem: Which of the following investigations you will order for case 28?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of chronic constipation with delayed meconium and an empty rectum is highly suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. A barium enema is a standard diagnostic investigation for this condition. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for a definitive diagnosis.

questions.stem: The proper management for case 28 is:
questions.explanation: The patient's clinical presentation points to Hirschsprung disease. The definitive treatment for this condition is surgical intervention.

questions.stem: Which of the following is true about Celiac disease?
options: Is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder
Is an immune-mediated disorder that may be associated with diabetes mellitus
Is due to atrophy of the villi within the colon
Is due to a lack of pancreatic exocrine enzyme function
questions.explanation: Celiac disease is described as an immune-mediated enteropathy induced by gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. It is associated with other autoimmune disorders like diabetes and thyroiditis. It affects the small intestine, not the colon, causing villous atrophy.

questions.stem: Which of the following is true regarding gastro-oesophageal reflux disease?
options: Can be a cause of apnea in infants
Is a cause of bilious vomiting
Is uncommon in children with severe physical disability
Is usually due to incompetent upper esophageal sphincter
questions.explanation: The textbook states that gastro-esophageal reflux (GER) can be a cause of apnea in infants. GER causes non-bilious vomiting, is common in children with severe physical disabilities, and is due to an incompetent lower esophageal sphincter, not the upper one.

questions.stem: Which of the following supports dysfunctional recurrent abdominal pain?
questions.explanation: Dysfunctional recurrent abdominal pain is typically vague, dull aching, and located periumbilically. Pain radiating to the back may suggest pancreatitis, and prolonged fever or weight loss would point toward an organic cause.

questions.stem: For a 16 kg boy, maintenance IV fluid requirement should be:
questions.explanation: The maintenance fluid requirement is calculated based on weight. For the first 10 kg, it's 100 ml/kg (so 10x100=1000 ml). For each kg from 11-20 kg, it's 50 ml/kg (so for the next 6 kg, it's 6x50=300 ml). The total is 1000+300=1300 ml per 24 hours.

questions.stem: The amount of oral rehydration solution for a 6 month old infant with diarrhea and mild dehydration is:
questions.explanation: The textbook states that for a child with mild dehydration, the amount of ORS to be given is 50-80 ml/kg. The most common initial dose in this range is 50 ml/kg.

questions.stem: Glucose in oral rehydration solution (ORS) is added to:
questions.explanation: The mechanism of action of ORS depends on glucose-facilitated sodium absorption, which helps in rehydration. While glucose provides some calories, its primary role in ORS is to aid sodium and water absorption.

questions.stem: The most common viral cause of gastroenteritis in infants is:
questions.explanation: The textbook lists Rotavirus as a common viral agent causing gastroenteritis.

questions.stem: The correct statement about ORS therapy is:
options: It can be given by nasogastric tube
It is used to stop diarrhea
It is used mainly in bacterial gastroenteritis
It should be given rapidly to correct dehydration
questions.explanation: ORS can be administered via a nasogastric tube in cases where the child is unconscious, uncooperative, or has persistent vomiting. ORS does not stop diarrhea; its function is to facilitate sodium and water absorption. It is effective for all types of microorganisms, not just bacteria. It should be given slowly to avoid vomiting.

questions.stem: The correct statement about ORS composition is:
options: Action depends on glucose-facilitated potassium absorption
Constituents include: Na, Cl, K, Glucose
Should be diluted in 100 ml water
questions.explanation: The composition of ORS includes sodium (Na), chloride (Cl), potassium (K), and glucose. Its action depends on glucose-facilitated sodium absorption, not potassium absorption. It is prepared by dissolving a packet in 1 liter of water, not 100 ml.

questions.stem: Which of the following is true about Celiac disease?
options: Eating gluten triggers an immune response in the large intestine.
It is an autosomal dominant disease
It is due to atrophy of the villi within the colon
It may be manifested by short stature
questions.explanation: Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder affecting the small intestine, characterized by villous atrophy. It can present in later childhood with growth failure or short stature, with or without gastrointestinal symptoms.

questions.stem: Gastro-esophageal reflux disease (GERD):
options: Can be a cause of apnea in infants
Is a cause of bilious vomiting
Is uncommon in children with severe physical disability
Is usually due to incompetent upper esophageal sphincter
questions.explanation: The textbook states that gastro-esophageal reflux (GERD) is a cause of apnea in infants. It is not a cause of bilious vomiting, as the gastric contents have not yet passed the pylorus. GERD is common in children with severe physical disabilities and is usually due to an incompetent lower esophageal sphincter, not the upper one.

questions.stem: Which of the following is true regarding lactose intolerance in a 4 year old child?
options: Is likely to cause blood and mucous in the stools
Is most likely temporary, secondary to acquired lactase deficiency
Is treated by amino-acid or soy protein based formula
Is usually due to a genetic deficiency of intestinal lactase enzyme
questions.explanation: Lactose intolerance is often secondary to acute gastroenteritis, which damages the intestinal mucosa and causes a temporary loss of the lactase enzyme. It presents with watery, acidic stools and is treated with a lactose-free formula for a few days. Bloody stools are a sign of cow's milk protein allergy.

questions.stem: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:
options: Can be associated with hyperchloremic alkalosis in severe cases
Is usually discovered with first feed
questions.explanation: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is treated by surgical pyloromyotomy. It is more common in boys and is typically discovered between 2-6 weeks of age, not with the first feed.

questions.stem: Which of the following is used to manage hypernatremic dehydration?
options: Glucose 4 ml/kg + insulin (1 unit insulin for 20 ml glucose 10%)
questions.explanation: For hypernatremic dehydration, the deficit fluid is a glucose/saline solution in a ratio of 3:1 or 2:1, which has a low sodium content to allow for a gradual reduction in serum sodium and prevent cerebral edema. Calcium gluconate is for hypocalcemia, and glucose with insulin is for diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.stem: Which condition is not associated with vomiting?
questions.explanation: Aminoacidopathies, Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), and intestinal obstruction are all causes of vomiting. Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets, which is not typically associated with vomiting.

questions.stem: Concerning oral lesions. What is the correct statement:
options: Herpangina is caused by Herpes simplex virus
Monilial stomatitis is characterized by multiple ulcers mostly on the tongue
Monilial stomatitis can be treated by nystatin or miconazole
Persistent Candida infection may be due to humoral immunodeficiency
questions.explanation: Monilial stomatitis (thrush) is caused by Candida albicans and is treated with oral nystatin or miconazole. Herpangina is caused by Coxsackievirus, not Herpes simplex. Monilial stomatitis presents with white plaques, not ulcers. Persistent Candida infection may be due to T-cell, not humoral, immunodeficiency.

questions.stem: The following is a cause of persistent diarrhea:
questions.explanation: Lactose intolerance is listed as a cause of persistent diarrhea. Overfeeding, oral ampicillin, and Rotavirus are causes of acute diarrhea.

questions.stem: Which is not a cause of bloody diarrhea?
questions.explanation: Rotavirus causes watery diarrhea. Enteroinvasive E. coli, Entameba histolytica, and Salmonella are all listed as causes of bloody diarrhea.

questions.stem: Gastroenteritis is commonly associated with:
questions.explanation: Hypokalemia is a common complication of severe gastroenteritis due to increased intestinal fluid loss. Metabolic acidosis is a common complication, not alkalosis.

questions.stem: Gastroenteritis is not complicated by
questions.explanation: Gastroenteritis can lead to acute kidney injury, convulsions, and Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC) as complications. It is more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to fluid loss, not hypercalcemia.

questions.stem: Convulsions in GE may be caused by:
questions.explanation: Convulsions in gastroenteritis can be caused by metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia and hypernatremia, as well as fever and toxins.

questions.stem: Investigations of gastroenteritis does not include :
questions.explanation: The diagnosis of gastroenteritis is primarily clinical. Investigations are aimed at identifying complications or the causative organism. These include blood gases, electrolytes, kidney function tests, and stool analysis. A lower endoscopy is not a routine investigation for gastroenteritis.

questions.stem: Concerning management of gastroenteritis. What is the correct statement:
options: Antibiotics are indicated in most cases
Anti-motility drugs can be tried in older children
Feeding should be stopped for at least 12 hours
It can be managed at home
questions.explanation: Mild-to-moderate gastroenteritis can be managed at home with oral rehydration therapy and continued feeding. Antibiotics are not indicated in most cases since many are viral. Anti-motility drugs are contraindicated. Feeding should be started shortly after rehydration begins, not stopped for 12 hours.

questions.stem: In gastro-esophageal reflux one of the following is wrong
options: Dystonic movements of head & neck may be associated
Symptoms usually start after 1st year of life
questions.explanation: Gastro-esophageal reflux (GER) symptoms usually start in infancy, often before the first year of life. It can be asymptomatic, most cases resolve spontaneously, and abnormal posturing (Sandifer syndrome) can be associated with severe cases.

questions.stem: Which is not a cause of oropharyngeal dysphagia?
questions.explanation: Esophagitis is a cause of esophageal dysphagia, characterized by difficulty in food transport through the esophagus. Cerebral palsy, scleroderma, and vascular ring are causes of oropharyngeal or mechanical dysphagia.

questions.stem: Regarding persistent diarrhea, which statement is correct?
options: In sugar intolerance the stool is bloody
In cow's milk allergy the stool is acidic
In bacterial overgrowth colonic bacteria invade upper part of small intestine
Vitamin D is the most important vitamin to be replaced
questions.explanation: The textbook states that in bacterial overgrowth, colonic bacteria invade the upper small intestine, leading to mucosal damage and persistent diarrhea. In sugar intolerance, the stool is acidic due to undigested sugars, while bloody stools are characteristic of cow's milk protein allergy.

questions.stem: The following is not a cause of emesis in childhood:
questions.explanation: Peptic ulcer is not mentioned as a cause of vomiting in the provided text. The textbook lists aminoacidopathies, hepatitis, and pertussis as causes of vomiting.

questions.stem: The most important step in treatment of acute gastro-enteritis in infants is:
options: Early oral antibiotics and constipating drugs
Early oral antibiotics and intestinal spasmolytic drugs
Early oral rehydration solution and continuation of breast feeding
Early oral rehydration solution and stop oral feeding
questions.explanation: The most important step is correction of dehydration with oral rehydration solution, followed by continuation of breast feeding or early re-feeding. The textbook explicitly states that antibiotics are not indicated in most cases and anti-motility drugs are contraindicated.

questions.stem: Which is a cause of acute abdominal pain?
questions.explanation: The textbook lists all of the above conditions as medical causes of acute abdominal pain. Diabetic ketoacidosis, lower lobe pneumonia, and pharyngitis (through mesenteric adenitis) can all present with abdominal pain.

questions.stem: Of the following, the most common symptom of gastroesophageal reflux disease in infants is:
questions.explanation: Regurgitation (non-forceful return of gastric contents) is the most common symptom of gastroesophageal reflux disease in infants. It is so common that it is often referred to as 'spitting up'.

questions.stem: Common symptoms of GERD include?
A nine month old infant developed acute watery diarrhea. He has runny nose and tachypnea with fever. Stool culture was free. With normal vital signs. The most likely diagnosis is:
A nine month old infant developed acute watery diarrhea. He has runny nose and tachypnea with fever. Stool culture was free. With normal vital signs. Treatment of this case must include:
A nine month old infant developed acute watery diarrhea. He has runny nose and tachypnea with fever. Stool culture was free The most common causative agent causing that is :

Mostafa, a 4 month old infant, presents with vomiting since the first week of life. The vomiting occurs daily, is usually small in amount, but occasionally is projectile. Physical examination reveals a happy infant who is thriving well. The breathing is noisy. DD is:

A 5 year old infant with intermittent, painful bright red blood per rectum for the past 3 months. Inspection of the anus shows no fissures but blood on rectal exam. Bleeding and coagulation time were normal . The most likely Diagnosis is:
First line of management of upper GI bleeding is:

5 year old infant with intermittent, painful bright red blood per rectum for the past months. Inspection of the anus shows no fissures but blood on rectal exam. Bleeding and coagulation time were normal. The most useful treatment is:
Gastrointestinal Causes of Cough
bloody diarrhea caused by all of the following except:
All are causes of chronic diarrhea except:
The most serious type of dehydration is
An infant who sits with only minimal support and who rolls over from supine to prone position, but does not say a word. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: An infant who sits with minimal support and rolls over from supine to prone is typically around 6 months of age. Rolling from supine to prone is an expected gross motor skill at this age. While the textbook states that sitting without support is a milestone for 6-7 months, a child at 6 months might be able to sit with minimal support as described in the question. The lack of speech is also normal for this age, as milestones like saying 'Mama' or 'Dada' are typically seen around 9-12 months.

questions.stem: An infant can move his head from side to side while following moving objects can lift his head from prone position 45 degrees off the examining table, smiles when encouraged but cannot maintain a seated position. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: At 3 months, an infant can follow moving objects and lift their head to 45 degrees in the prone position. They also begin to smile on social contact, which is noted in the textbook as a 2-month milestone but is well-established by 3 months. The inability to sit without support is consistent with a 3-month-old infant, as this skill develops later, around 6-7 months.

questions.stem: An infant can move his head from side to side while following moving object, can lift his head from prone position 45 degrees off the examining table, smiles when encouraged and can sit without support. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: An infant who can follow moving objects, lift their head 45 degrees in the prone position, and smiles when encouraged would be at least 3 months old. However, the key feature is the ability to sit without support. The textbook lists sitting without support as a milestone achieved at 6-7 months. Therefore, 7 months is the most likely age that includes all the described skills.

questions.stem: A child is brought to your clinic for routine examination. She can dress with help. knows her own age and can speak short sentences. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: At 3 years of age, a child can dress with help, knows their full name and age, and can speak in three-word sentences. This combination of skills makes 3 years the most probable age. The ability to dress with help is a fine motor and social skill typically acquired during the preschool years.

questions.stem: An infant can stand unsupported, walk with support and says 2 meaningful words. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: A 12-month-old infant can stand with support and walks with a wide gait, though unsteadily. They may also be able to say 2-3 words. The textbook notes that an infant can stand with support at 11 months, walk with support at 10 months and walk unsteadily at 12 months, and says 2-3 words at one year old, making 12 months the most accurate age.

questions.stem: An infant can walk unsupported, points to several body parts, climbs over furniture and can ascend or descend stairs. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: An infant who can walk unsupported and climb over furniture is typically around 18 months to 2 years old. The ability to ascend stairs in a child-like manner (step-by-step) is a milestone for a 2-year-old. The ability to point to several body parts and climb over furniture is consistent with a 2-year-old's developmental stage.

questions.stem: An infant can wave bye-bye, points to body parts and feed with spoon. He walks unsupported, but still unable to give full name, age and sex. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: A child who can walk unsupported, point to body parts, and feed with a spoon is likely a toddler. The ability to walk unsupported is a 15-month milestone, and feeding with a spoon is an 18-month social behavior. The ability to point to parts of the body is a 2-year-old skill. However, the key is that the child is still unable to give their full name, age, and sex, which is a developmental milestone for 3 years. Therefore, 2 years is the most likely age.

questions.stem: A child is brought to your clinic for routine examination. He can descend stairs like an adult, know her own age, recognize most of colors, and can speak short sentences. Which of the following is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.explanation: The combination of descending stairs like an adult, knowing their age, recognizing most colors, and speaking short sentences points to a 4-year-old. While a 3-year-old can give their full name and age, descending stairs 'like an adult' is a skill developed at 4 years.

questions.stem: A child can jump and starts to hop, can copy a square, can draw a person with three parts and dress with supervision but still unable to write his name. Which of the following is the most likely age of the child?
questions.explanation: A child who can jump and starts to hop is developing skills seen between 3 and 5 years. The ability to copy a square is a 4-year-old skill. Drawing a person with three parts is a skill acquired around 4 years. Dressing with supervision is appropriate for this age, while the inability to write their name is expected, as this is a later skill.

questions.stem: You are evaluating a 15 months old infant for motor and mental development. He can walk alone, wave bye-bye and says 3 words. He has difficulty in ascending stairs. You are going to tell the mother that
options: Her infant has a mental delay
Her infant has a motor delay.
We need to do an x ray to exclude rickets.
questions.explanation: At 15 months, an infant is expected to be able to walk alone and says 2-3 words. Waving 'bye-bye' is a milestone for 12 months. Ascending stairs is a skill that develops later, at 2 years, with a child-like manner (step-by-step). The difficulty in ascending stairs at 15 months is, therefore, a normal finding and does not indicate a developmental delay.

questions.stem: During examination of a 7 months old infant, you notice that he can support his head, recognize his mother, sit unsupported but he does not respond to his own name. You are going to tell the mother that:
options: Her infant has a mental delay.
Her infant has a motor delay.
questions.explanation: At 7 months, an infant can support his head, recognize his mother, and sit unsupported. Not responding to his own name is a key point, but the textbook states that this is a 9-month milestone, which means it is not yet expected at 7 months, so the child is developmentally normal.

questions.stem: A child is brought to your clinic for routine follow up. She can identify three colors, say her full name, age and sex, ascend and descend stairs in an adult manner, can draw a man with all features and can write her name. Which of the following is the most likely age of the child?
questions.explanation: A child who can identify colors, give their full name, age, and sex, ascend and descend stairs in an adult manner, draw a man with all features, and write their name is typically 5-6 years old. The combination of identifying colors, speaking full details about self, and drawing a person with all features points to a 4-5 year age range, but the ability to write their name pushes it to 5-6 years. Since 5 years is not an option, 4 years is the closest age.

questions.stem: A child is brought to your clinic for a routine examination. She can dress with help, make a tower of 10 cubes, knows her own name and age and can say short sentences. She had difficulty in copying a square. The age of this child is most likely?
questions.explanation: A child who can dress with help, make a tower of 10 cubes, knows their own name and age, and can say short sentences is at the 3-year-old developmental stage. A tower of 8 cubes is a 2.5-year milestone, so a tower of 10 cubes is appropriate for a 3-year-old. Speaking short sentences and knowing name and age are 3-year-old milestones. The difficulty in copying a square is also normal, as this is a 4-year-old skill. Since 36 months equals 3 years, this is the correct age.

questions.stem: An infant, lies smiling, and babbling, he can roll over, sits briefly, leaning forward on his hands, with rounded back. He can stand with support, he reaches out and grasps for large objects using the palms, and laughs and giggles when shown himself in the mirror. Estimated age of development is?
questions.explanation: An infant who smiles and babbles is typically around 8 months. Rolling over is a milestone at 8 months. Sitting briefly leaning forward with hands is consistent with 7 months. Standing with support is an 11-month milestone. Laughing and giggling is also a milestone at 8 months. Reaching and grasping with the palms is an older skill, but the combination of all these milestones, including the early development of standing with support, makes 9 months the most comprehensive age range for all the described skills.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old girl presents with short stature. Her height is less than the 5th percentile, and her weight is in 10th percentile. Heart auscultation revealed ejection systolic murmur on the left sternal border. What would the most useful investigation be?
questions.explanation: The patient is a 5-year-old girl with short stature and an ejection systolic murmur. The combination of short stature and a cardiac anomaly, specifically an ejection systolic murmur, should raise suspicion for a genetic or chromosomal disorder. Turner syndrome (45, XO) is a chromosomal disorder that typically presents with short stature and is associated with cardiac anomalies such as coarctation of the aorta. Karyotyping is the definitive test to diagnose Turner syndrome.

questions.stem: A 7 year old boy presents to your clinic for evaluation of short stature. Parents report that he has always been the shortest boy in his class. He has been well with no chronic medical problems. His height is below the 5th percentile with weight on the 25th percentile. His mother is 145 cm. The patient's father is 155 cm. There is no family history of any medical problems. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The child is a 7-year-old boy with short stature below the 5th percentile. However, his weight is on the 25th percentile, which is within the normal range. His parents are also short (145 cm and 155 cm), suggesting a familial pattern. The key characteristics of familial short stature are a family history of short stature, short parents, a short healthy child from birth, normal growth velocity, normal bone age, and normal puberty. This case fits the description of familial short stature.

questions.stem: A 7 year old boy presents to your clinic for evaluation of short stature. He has no history of any chronic symptoms. His Height is below the 5th percentile with weight on the 10th percentile. He has no abnormal features. What is the first most appropriate step to do?
options: Measure the height of the mother and father.
Serum protein and full blood count.
questions.explanation: The first step in evaluating a child with short stature is a detailed history and physical examination, which includes measuring the height of the parents. Most cases of short stature are normal variants, either familial or constitutional. Determining the mid-parental height helps to establish if the child's height is within their genetic potential.

questions.stem: This is a 12 year old boy who is seen by his physician for short stature. His past medical history is normal. No family history of short stature but he has an older male sibling age 18 years with history of delayed onset of puberty. What is most likely the cause of short stature?
options: Constitutional delay in growth and puberty.
questions.explanation: The patient is a 12-year-old boy with short stature. The key clue is the family history of an older male sibling with a history of delayed onset of puberty. This strongly suggests a familial pattern of constitutional delay in growth and puberty. In constitutional delay, children are of normal length at birth but become short within 2 years, have a delayed bone age, and delayed puberty, but their final adult height is normal. This is a common problem in boys.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old boy presents with proportionate short stature. His height is less than the 5th percentile, and his weight is in 10th percentile. He is asymptomatic with normal features. His mid-parental height percentile was the 50th. What is the most useful investigation?
questions.explanation: The patient is a 5-year-old boy with proportionate short stature and a mid-parental height percentile of 50th, which means his genetic potential is for normal height. This excludes familial short stature. The child is asymptomatic with normal features, making skeletal dysplasia and chromosomal disorders less likely. Therefore, an endocrinological cause such as growth hormone deficiency should be investigated. The initial investigation is a growth hormone assay, which is part of the endocrinal assessment if bone age is markedly delayed.

questions.stem: A 3-year-old child with short stature, height below the 5th percentile, upper segment to lower segment ratio is 1.5/1. Which of the following investigation is most likely to be helpful?
options: Endocrine testing for growth hormone level and pituitary function.
questions.explanation: The child is 3 years old with short stature and an upper segment to lower segment ratio of 1.5:1. The normal ratio at 3 years is 1.3:1. A ratio of 1.5:1 is increased, which indicates disproportionate short stature with short limbs. Causes of disproportionate short stature include achondroplasia, rickets, and congenital hypothyroidism. A skeletal survey is the most helpful investigation for diagnosing these conditions.

questions.stem: A 13-year-old boy was reviewed at school for moderate learning difficulties. His height was more than the 95th percentile with weight at the 50th percentile. He had bilateral testicular volumes of 2ml and no pubic or axillary hair. His mid-parental height percentile was the 50th. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The patient is a 13-year-old boy with a height greater than the 95th percentile and delayed puberty, as evidenced by small testicular volumes of 2 ml and a lack of pubic and axillary hair. Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is a sex chromosomal abnormality in males that presents with a disproportionate tall stature and hypogonadism, including small testes and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics.

questions.stem: The parents of a 14 year old boy are concerned about his short stature and lack of sexual development. He had a normal growth pattern, although he was always shorter than children of his age. Examination revealed height at the 5th percentile, upper segment to lower segment ratio is 0.98. A small number of fine axillary and pubic hairs are present. Which of the following is the most appropriate action?
options: Obtain a CT scan of pituitary gland..
questions.explanation: The patient is a 14-year-old boy with short stature at the 5th percentile and a lack of sexual development. He has a normal growth pattern, always being shorter than his peers. His upper segment to lower segment ratio is 0.98, which is close to the adult ratio of 1:1. These findings are characteristic of constitutional delay in growth and puberty. The textbook states that this condition is common in boys and reassurance is the appropriate management, as the child's adult height will be normal.

questions.stem: An otherwise healthy 6-year-old girl is brought to you to be evaluated because he is the shortest child in his class, careful measurement of his upper and lower segments demonstrates normal body proportions for his age Which of the following disorders of growth is most likely?
questions.explanation: The child is a 6-year-old boy with short stature who is the shortest in his class, but his body proportions (upper and lower segments) are normal for his age. Normal body proportions indicate proportionate short stature. Achondroplasia is a cause of disproportionate short stature with short limbs. Marfan syndrome is a cause of tall stature. Mucopolysaccharidosis can cause short stature, but it is often disproportionate with a short trunk. Growth hormone deficiency is a cause of proportionate short stature, normal mentality, and normal body proportions, making it the most likely diagnosis.

questions.stem: An 18-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for follow up. He has been healthy since birth. During the examination, the baby walks and runs, and his mother states that he can climb stairs. However, he has not been observed to jump. He is able to grasp objects with his finger and thumb and bang cubes together. Which of the following assessments of his motor development is correct?
options: Delayed gross motor skills, delayed fine motor skills
Delayed gross motor skills, normal fine motor skills
Normal gross motor skills, delayed fine motor skills.
Normal gross motor skills, normal fine motor skills.
questions.explanation: The child is 18 months old. At this age, the textbook states that a child can walk unsupported. Running is a skill of a 2-year-old, and climbing stairs is an 18-month milestone. Therefore, the patient's gross motor skills are normal. Grasping objects with the finger and thumb (mature pincer grasp) is a milestone for 12 months, and banging cubes together is a fine motor skill appropriate for this age. Jumping is a later gross motor skill, acquired around 2 years old, so the child's inability to jump is not a delay.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician because her parents are concerned that she is not talking as well as her older sister did at the same age. She is able to point to 4 pictures and combines 2 words together and sometimes 3 words together. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: The child is a 2-year-old girl. At 2 years of age, a child is expected to be able to say about 10 words and join words together. The child in the question can point to 4 pictures and combine 2-3 words, which is within the normal range for this age. Language development varies among children, and a parent's concern based on an older sibling is not a reliable indicator of a disorder. This child's language skills are within the normal range for a 2-year-old.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old boy is brought to your office because his mother is concerned that he is not eating enough and may need vitamins. On growth curve, his weight is at the 97th percentile for age and 50th percentile for height. Physical examination is otherwise normal. Which of the following statements best reflects the appropriate management for this child?
options: A dietary history should be taken.
No intervention is required at this time
Subcutaneous skin fold thickness should be followed closely.
